page.title: 12LES ECREHOUS
page.content: Les Ecrehous are a reef of rocks, situated off the north-eastern corner of Jersey, and administered by the Parish of St. Martin. There are several huts which belong to local fishermen, and are used by them frequently, though none is permanently occupied. During the 19th century {Philippe Pinel}lived there on his own for many years, and was nicknamed the {'King of the Ecrehous'. They are the site of one of the oldest 'lighthouses' in the British Isles, for in 1203 a small priory was built there with a fund to 'burn a candle in the window each night', and this was done for more than three centuries. In 1953, after a dispute about sovereignty between Britain and France, the International Court of Justice decided in favour of Britain.
